title.narrative: EISA, 2014-18 Africa Dem Strength Program III
EISA, 2014-18 Africa Dem Strengthening Program III

description.narrative: EISA supports free and fair elections and participatory democracy in Africa. The operations include support to election observation, election authorities, political parties, parliaments and regional institutions (AU).

Sida har samarbetat med EISA sedan 1999. EISA arbetar f.a. med att främja fria och rättvisa val och en deltagande demokrati i Afrika. Verksamheten omfattar bl.a. stöd till valövervakning genom utbildning av civila samhällets organisationer, valmyndigheter och regionala institutioner samt stöd till politiska partier, parlament och regionala organsiationer (AU). EISA har ansökt om stöd uppgående till 40 MSEK för en tredje fas av Africa Democracy Strengthening Programme, ADS III för perioden 2014-2017. Andra givare är DfID. Det övergripande målet med programmet är bättre valprocesser som i sin tur ska bidra till en livaktig demokrati i afrikanska länder. Sida bedömer att insatsen är högst relevant utifrån både svensk och afrikansk policykontext. Vidare bedöms förutsättningarna för effektivitet, genomförbarhet och hållbarhet vara goda. Sammantagen risknivå bedöms vara medelhög till hög f.a. på grund av politisk och institutionell osäkerhet i den kontext som EISA arbetar i. Korruptionsrisken bedöms vara låg till medelhög.

The intended outcome of the ADS III programme is stronger and more effective democratic institutions, with greater citizen participation at sub-regional and continental levels and in selected African countries. This will contribute to the intended impact of more credible electoral and democratic political processes in Africa.

participating-org.narrative: EISA/Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa
EISA/Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: On an overall level, EISA concludes that intergovernmental bodies on the African continent have made improvements in the frameworks that govern their engagement in member states' electoral processes, but that election observation efforts are still mostly limited to assessing elections in the immediate voting day phase. RECs are, according to EISA, hampered by funding challenges and the fact that greater focus is placed on peace and security matters. Main highlights over the full programme period mentioned include: Introduction of tablets and Open Data Kit Technology to AUEOMs, 2015-2015, which allows for real-time transmission of observation data and quick output of data analysis. The EAC followed in 2016. EISA started support to ECCAS in 2014, who now has an observation handbook, and a draft document on Principles to govern democratic elections. In 2016 the first joint AU and ECCAS EOM was deployed to Gabon. ECOWAS has since 2016 been supported to adopt a more cycle-based approach, including needs assessments, and pre- and post-election observation. From EISA's own independent EOMs, one concrete result highlighted is the amended legal framework to govern presidential elections in Zambia, based on recommendations from EISA. From the work with parliament and political parties in Madagascar, EISA puts forward the gender mainstreaming work, which has contributed to reform of the Nationality Code in 2017, improving gender equality in the country. This was, amongst others, based on a review of laws and policies in relation to regional and international protocols on the rights of women. EISA's work with MPs has led to increased interaction with citizens and more transparency, according to the report.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
